openwave.core.equations

Energy Wave Theory (EWT) equations module.

This module implements the core mathematical equations of Energy Wave Theory including:

Energy Equations: - Energy wave equation (fundamental EWT equation) - Particle energy (longitudinal waves) - Photon energy, frequency, and wavelength (transverse waves)

Force Equations: - Electric force (charged particle interactions) - Magnetic force (moving charge interactions) - Gravitational force (mass interactions via amplitude loss) - Strong force (nuclear binding) - Orbital force (electron orbital mechanics)

Relativistic Wave Energy: - Longitudinal in-wave energy (relativistic particles) - Longitudinal out-wave energy (with spin corrections) - Magnetic out-wave energy (transverse component)

Unit Converters: - Energy unit conversions (J, eV, kWh, cal)

All equations are derived from the fundamental Energy Wave Equation and use EWT-specific constants from the constants module.

Functions

J_to_eV(energy_J)

Convert joules to electron-volts.

J_to_kWh(energy_J)

Convert joules to kilowatt-hours.

eV_to_J(energy_eV)

Convert electron-volts to joules.

electric_force(Q1, Q2, r[, Ke, Oe, g_lambda])

Electric Force: F_e = (4πρK_e^7 A_l^6 c^2 O_e / 3λ_l^2) * g_λ * (Q1*Q2 / r^2)

energy_wave_equation(volume)

Energy Wave Equation: E = ρV(c/λl * A)² The fundamental equation from which all EWT equations are derived.

gravitational_force(Q1, Q2, r[, Ke, Oe, ...])

Gravitational Force: F_g = (ρλ_l^2 c^2 O_e / 2K_e^31) * (A_l/36)^2 * g_λ^3 * g_p^2 * (Q1*Q2 / r^2)

kWh_to_J(energy_kWh)

Convert kilowatt-hours to joules.

longitudinal_in_wave_energy(K, v[, ...])

Longitudinal In-Wave Energy - Complete Form E_l(in) = (1/2) * ρ * (4π/3 * K * λl)³ * [(c * (Ke*Al)³) / (λl * √(1 + v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]² * [(c * (Ke*Al)³) / (λl * √(1 - v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]²

longitudinal_out_wave_energy(K, v[, ...])

Longitudinal Out-Wave Energy - Complete Form E_l(out) = (1/2) * ρ * (4π/3 * K * λl)³ * [(c * (Ke*Al)³ * Ke * (Al - Al*√αGe)) / (λl * √(1 + v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]² * [(c * (Ke*Al)³ * Ke * (Al + Al*√αGe)) / (λl * √(1 - v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]²

magnetic_force(Q1, Q2, r, v[, Ke, Oe, g_lambda])

Magnetic Force: F_m = (4πρK_e^7 A_l^6 O_e / 3λ_l^2) * g_λ * (Q1*Q2*v^2 / r^2)

magnetic_out_wave_energy(K, v[, wavelength, ...])

Magnetic (Transverse) Out-Wave Energy - Complete Form E_m(out) = (1/αe) * ρ * lp³ * [(c * (Ke*Al)³) / (Ke²*λl * √(1 + 1/c) * (Ke²*λl)²)]² * [(c * (Ke*Al)³ * √(1/αGe)) / (Ke²*λl * √(1 - 1/c) * (Ke²*λl)²)]² * gλ*gA

orbital_force(Q, r[, Ke, g_lambda])

Orbital Force: F_o = (64ρK_e^17 A_l^8 c^2 O_e / 27πλ_l^3) * g_λ^2 * (Q^2 / r^3)

particle_energy(K)

Longitudinal Energy Equation (Particles): E_l(K) = (4πρK⁵A_l⁶c²/3λ_l³) * Σ(n=1 to K)[n³-(n-1)³]/n⁴ Used to calculate the rest energy of particles.

photon_energy(delta, r, r0[, Ke, Oe])

Transverse Energy Equation (Photons): E_t = (2πρK_e^7 A_l^6 c^2 O_e / 3λ_l^2) * ((δ/r) - (δ/r_0))

photon_frequency(delta, r, r0[, Ke])

Photon Frequency: f = (3λ_l c / 16K_e^4 A_l) * ((δ/r) - (δ/r_0))

photon_wavelength(delta, r, r0[, Ke])

Photon Wavelength: λ_t = (16K_e^4 A_l / 3λ_l) * (1 / ((δ/r) - (δ/r_0)))

strong_force(Q1, Q2, r[, Ke, Oe, g_lambda])

Strong Force: F_s = (16ρK_e^11 A_l^7 c^2 O_e / 9λ_l^3) * g_λ * (Q1*Q2 / r^2)
openwave.core.equations.energy_wave_equation(volume)[source]

Energy Wave Equation: E = ρV(c/λl * A)² The fundamental equation from which all EWT equations are derived. :type volume: :param volume: Volume V in m³ :type volume: float

Returns:

Energy E in Joules

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.particle_energy(K)[source]

Longitudinal Energy Equation (Particles): E_l(K) = (4πρK⁵A_l⁶c²/3λ_l³) * Σ(n=1 to K)[n³-(n-1)³]/n⁴ Used to calculate the rest energy of particles. :type K: :param K: Particle wave center count (dimensionless) :type K: int

Returns:

Particle energy E_l in Joules

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.photon_energy(delta, r, r0, Ke=10, Oe=2.13874382)[source]

Transverse Energy Equation (Photons): E_t = (2πρK_e^7 A_l^6 c^2 O_e / 3λ_l^2) * ((δ/r) - (δ/r_0))

Used to calculate the energy of photons emitted or absorbed by particles.

Parameters:

  • delta (float) – Amplitude factor (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Current distance from particle center in meters

  • r0 (float) – Initial/reference distance from particle center in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

  • Oe (float) – Outer shell multiplier (default: electron outer shell)

Returns:

Photon energy E_t in Joules

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.photon_frequency(delta, r, r0, Ke=10)[source]

Photon Frequency: f = (3λ_l c / 16K_e^4 A_l) * ((δ/r) - (δ/r_0))

Calculates the frequency of a photon based on amplitude changes at different distances.

Parameters:

  • delta (float) – Amplitude factor (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Current distance from particle center in meters

  • r0 (float) – Initial/reference distance from particle center in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

Returns:

Photon frequency f in Hz

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.photon_wavelength(delta, r, r0, Ke=10)[source]

Photon Wavelength: λ_t = (16K_e^4 A_l / 3λ_l) * (1 / ((δ/r) - (δ/r_0)))

Calculates the wavelength of a photon based on amplitude changes at different distances.

Parameters:

  • delta (float) – Amplitude factor (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Current distance from particle center in meters

  • r0 (float) – Initial/reference distance from particle center in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

Returns:

Photon wavelength λ_t in meters

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.electric_force(Q1, Q2, r, Ke=10, Oe=2.13874382, g_lambda=0.987331832)[source]

Electric Force: F_e = (4πρK_e^7 A_l^6 c^2 O_e / 3λ_l^2) * g_λ * (Q1*Q2 / r^2)

Force between charged particles based on particle energy at distance.

Parameters:

  • Q1 (float) – Charge/particle count of first particle (dimensionless)

  • Q2 (float) – Charge/particle count of second particle (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Distance between particles in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

  • Oe (float) – Outer shell multiplier (default: electron)

  • g_lambda (float) – Orbital g-factor (default: electron)

Returns:

Electric force F_e in Newtons

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.magnetic_force(Q1, Q2, r, v, Ke=10, Oe=2.13874382, g_lambda=0.987331832)[source]

Magnetic Force: F_m = (4πρK_e^7 A_l^6 O_e / 3λ_l^2) * g_λ * (Q1*Q2*v^2 / r^2)

Electromagnetic force for particles in motion (induced current).

Parameters:

  • Q1 (float) – Charge/particle count of first particle (dimensionless)

  • Q2 (float) – Charge/particle count of second particle (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Distance between particles in meters

  • v (float) – Relative velocity of particles in m/s

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

  • Oe (float) – Outer shell multiplier (default: electron)

  • g_lambda (float) – Orbital g-factor (default: electron)

Returns:

Magnetic force F_m in Newtons

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.gravitational_force(Q1, Q2, r, Ke=10, Oe=2.13874382, g_lambda=0.987331832, g_p=0.98981253)[source]

Gravitational Force: F_g = (ρλ_l^2 c^2 O_e / 2K_e^31) * (A_l/36)^2 * g_λ^3 * g_p^2 * (Q1*Q2 / r^2)

Force based on amplitude loss in wave interactions.

Parameters:

  • Q1 (float) – Mass/particle count of first particle (dimensionless)

  • Q2 (float) – Mass/particle count of second particle (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Distance between particles in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

  • Oe (float) – Outer shell multiplier (default: electron)

  • g_lambda (float) – Electron orbital g-factor (default: electron)

  • g_p (float) – Proton orbital g-factor (default: proton)

Returns:

Gravitational force F_g in Newtons

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.strong_force(Q1, Q2, r, Ke=10, Oe=2.13874382, g_lambda=0.987331832)[source]

Strong Force: F_s = (16ρK_e^11 A_l^7 c^2 O_e / 9λ_l^3) * g_λ * (Q1*Q2 / r^2)

Nuclear force keeping particles bound in atomic nuclei.

Parameters:

  • Q1 (float) – Particle count of first particle (dimensionless)

  • Q2 (float) – Particle count of second particle (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Distance between particles in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

  • Oe (float) – Outer shell multiplier (default: electron)

  • g_lambda (float) – Orbital g-factor (default: electron)

Returns:

Strong force F_s in Newtons

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.orbital_force(Q, r, Ke=10, g_lambda=0.987331832)[source]

Orbital Force: F_o = (64ρK_e^17 A_l^8 c^2 O_e / 27πλ_l^3) * g_λ^2 * (Q^2 / r^3)

Force keeping electrons in orbit around atomic nuclei.

Parameters:

  • Q (float) – Particle/charge count (dimensionless)

  • r (float) – Orbital radius in meters

  • Ke (int) – Particle wave center count (default: electron K=10)

  • g_lambda (float) – Orbital g-factor (default: electron)

Returns:

Orbital force F_o in Newtons

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.longitudinal_in_wave_energy(K, v, wavelength=None, amplitude=None)[source]

Longitudinal In-Wave Energy - Complete Form E_l(in) = (1/2) * ρ * (4π/3 * K * λl)³ * [(c * (Ke*Al)³) / (λl * √(1 + v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]²

  • [(c * (Ke*Al)³) / (λl * √(1 - v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]²

Calculates the in-wave energy for particles at relativistic speeds. The complete form includes relativistic wavelength changes.

Parameters:

  • K (int) – Particle wave center count (dimensionless)

  • v (float) – Particle velocity in m/s

  • wavelength (float, optional) – Wavelength in meters. If None, uses QWAVE_LENGTH

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude in meters. If None, uses QWAVE_AMPLITUDE

Returns:

Longitudinal in-wave energy in Joules

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.longitudinal_out_wave_energy(K, v, wavelength=None, amplitude=None, g_lambda=0.987331832, g_A=0.9826905018)[source]

Longitudinal Out-Wave Energy - Complete Form E_l(out) = (1/2) * ρ * (4π/3 * K * λl)³ *

[(c * (Ke*Al)³ * Ke * (Al - Al*√αGe)) / (λl * √(1 + v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]² * [(c * (Ke*Al)³ * Ke * (Al + Al*√αGe)) / (λl * √(1 - v/c) * (Ke*λl)²)]²

Calculates the out-wave energy for particles at relativistic speeds. Includes amplitude loss due to particle spin (important for gravity/magnetism).

Parameters:

  • K (int) – Particle wave center count (dimensionless)

  • v (float) – Particle velocity in m/s

  • wavelength (float, optional) – Wavelength in meters. If None, uses QWAVE_LENGTH

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude in meters. If None, uses QWAVE_AMPLITUDE

  • g_lambda (float) – Orbital g-factor (default: electron)

  • g_A (float) – Spin g-factor (default: electron)

Returns:

Longitudinal out-wave energy in Joules

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.magnetic_out_wave_energy(K, v, wavelength=None, amplitude=None, g_lambda=0.987331832, g_A=0.9826905018)[source]

Magnetic (Transverse) Out-Wave Energy - Complete Form E_m(out) = (1/αe) * ρ * lp³ * [(c * (Ke*Al)³) / (Ke²*λl * √(1 + 1/c) * (Ke²*λl)²)]² *

[(c * (Ke*Al)³ * √(1/αGe)) / (Ke²*λl * √(1 - 1/c) * (Ke²*λl)²)]² * gλ*gA

Calculates the transverse (magnetic) out-wave energy for particles at relativistic speeds. This is related to magnetic field generation by moving charges.

Parameters:

  • K (int) – Particle wave center count (dimensionless)

  • v (float) – Particle velocity in m/s

  • wavelength (float, optional) – Wavelength in meters. If None, uses QWAVE_LENGTH

  • amplitude (float, optional) – Amplitude in meters. If None, uses QWAVE_AMPLITUDE

  • g_lambda (float) – Orbital g-factor (default: electron)

  • g_A (float) – Spin g-factor (default: electron)

Returns:

Magnetic (transverse) out-wave energy in Joules

Return type:

float

openwave.core.equations.J_to_eV(energy_J)[source]

Convert joules to electron-volts.

Return type:

float

Parameters:

energy_J (float)

openwave.core.equations.eV_to_J(energy_eV)[source]

Convert electron-volts to joules.

float

energy_eV (float)
